<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 117, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 193, 366, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 246, 504, 262]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 285]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 287, 539, 318]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 336, 227, 351]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 352, 133, 366]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 351, 116, 366]]<|/det|>
<label>OR</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 352, 599, 368]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 368, 907, 399]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 399, 578, 414]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 415, 275, 429]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 430, 868, 460]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 460, 327, 475]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 476, 364, 490]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 491, 327, 505]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 506, 680, 522]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(9.8\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 9.8\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 570, 615]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40. Each correct answer will score one mark. Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 462, 88]]<|/det|> Which list contains only vector quantities? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 133, 116]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 100, 395, 116]]<|/det|> acceleration, distance, speed <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 143]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 125, 494, 142]]<|/det|> electric field strength, momentum, weight <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 133, 168]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 152, 376, 168]]<|/det|> energy, mass, temperature <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 195]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 178, 314, 195]]<|/det|> force, time, velocity <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 96, 240]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 222, 920, 255]]<|/det|> The graph shows how the velocity of an elevator varies with time. its weightits acceleration when the same
horizontal resultant force is applied

<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 816, 91]]<|/det|>
A box of mass \(2.0 \text{kg}\) slides down a slope. The gravitational field strength is \(9.8 \text{N / kg}\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 100, 722, 271]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 281, 905, 301]]<|/det|>
What is the decrease in the gravitational potential energy stored as the box moves from P to Q?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 310, 138, 329]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 310, 195, 329]]<|/det|>
9.8 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 310, 304, 329]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 310, 356, 329]]<|/det|>
98 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 310, 473, 329]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 310, 533, 329]]<|/det|>
240 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 310, 640, 329]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[645, 310, 700, 329]]<|/det|>
250 J

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the path of a long-jumper. Point R, where she lands, is on the same horizontal level as point P, from where she takes off. The long-jumper experiences air resistance as she runs and jumps.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 128, 803, 205]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 216, 920, 250]]<|/det|>
Which graph shows how the store of kinetic energy and the store of gravitational potential energy of the long-jumper vary with time between points P and R?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 259, 905, 685]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 713, 107, 732]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 713, 499, 732]]<|/det|>
Four tanks contain water to the depths shown.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 744, 692, 762]]<|/det|>
At the bottom of which tank is the pressure due to the water greatest?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 770, 920, 865]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 428, 89]]<|/det|>
A gas is heated in a sealed container.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 497, 120]]<|/det|>
The volume of the container does not change.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 462, 149]]<|/det|>
What happens to the particles of the gas?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 160, 134, 178]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 160, 571, 178]]<|/det|>
The average distance between particles increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 187, 134, 205]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 186, 593, 203]]<|/det|>
The average kinetic energy of the particles increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 212, 134, 231]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 212, 455, 230]]<|/det|>
The mass of each particle increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 238, 134, 257]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 238, 472, 256]]<|/det|>
The volume of each particle increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 282, 106, 301]]<|/det|>
<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 282, 920, 317]]<|/det|>
Air in a sealed syringe is slowly compressed by moving the piston. The temperature of the air stays the same.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 325, 660, 440]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 452, 457, 470]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the air is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 481, 134, 499]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 481, 803, 499]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the air decreases because its particles now travel more slowly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 508, 134, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 508, 871, 526]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the air decreases because the area of the syringe walls is now smaller.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 534, 131, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 534, 920, 567]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the air increases because its particles now hit the syringe walls more frequently.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 575, 133, 593]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 575, 803, 593]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the air increases because its particles now travel more quickly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 617, 106, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>14</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 617, 618, 636]]<|/det|>
Which statement about the evaporation of a liquid is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 647, 134, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 647, 920, 680]]<|/det|>
The least energetic particles escape from the surface and the temperature of the liquid decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 688, 131, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 688, 920, 720]]<|/det|>
The least energetic particles escape from the surface and the temperature of the liquid increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 730, 131, 747]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 730, 920, 762]]<|/det|>
The most energetic particles escape from the surface and the temperature of the liquid decreases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 771, 133, 789]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 771, 920, 803]]<|/det|>
The most energetic particles escape from the surface and the temperature of the liquid increases.

A vertical stick is dipped up and down in water at P.

In two seconds, three wave crests spread out on the surface of the water.

<label>C</label>

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 448, 106, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 499, 467]]<|/det|>
A single ray of light is reflected by two mirrors.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 479, 571, 498]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the ray of light incident on mirror 1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[321, 507, 675, 631]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

50°

<label>B</label>

primary and secondary coilscore

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 500, 104, 517]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 500, 920, 533]]<|/det|> The products of the decay of a nucleus of a radioactive isotope are a nucleus and radiation which is emitted. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 545, 408, 562]]<|/det|> What is the nature of the products? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 574, 134, 592]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 574, 920, 609]]<|/det|> a nucleus of an element different from the isotope is formed and both an \(\alpha\) -particle and \(\gamma\) -radiation are emitted <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 617, 131, 635]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 617, 890, 636]]<|/det|> a nucleus of an element different from the isotope is formed and just \(\gamma\) -radiation is emitted <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 644, 131, 662]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 644, 920, 677]]<|/det|> a nucleus of the same element as the isotope is formed and both a \(\beta\) -particle and \(\gamma\) -radiation are emitted <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 686, 131, 704]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 686, 875, 704]]<|/det|> a nucleus of the same element as the isotope is formed and just an \(\alpha\) -particle is emitted <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 730, 107, 748]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 730, 707, 748]]<|/det|> An atomic nucleus decays by one or more radioactive decay processes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 761, 541, 778]]<|/det|> What causes the proton number to **decrease** by 1? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 790, 134, 808]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 790, 391, 808]]<|/det|> \(\alpha\) -decay followed by \(\beta\) -decay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 817, 134, 835]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 817, 262, 835]]<|/det|> \(\alpha\) -decay only <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 845, 131, 863]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 845, 386, 863]]<|/det|> \(\beta\) -decay followed by \(\gamma\) -decay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 873, 134, 890]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 873, 260, 890]]<|/det|> \(\beta\) -decay only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 462, 89]]<|/det|> Which definition of half-life is **not** correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 892, 117]]<|/det|> the time it takes for the count rate from a radioactive sample to fall to half its original value <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 127, 131, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 126, 799, 144]]<|/det|> the time it takes for half of the unstable nuclei in a radioactive sample to decay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 153, 131, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 152, 750, 170]]<|/det|> the time it takes for the mass of radioactive material in a sample to halve <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 179, 131, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 178, 745, 196]]<|/det|> the time it takes for half of the neutrons in a radioactive sample to decay <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 106, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 831, 241]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a system to control the thickness of paper produced by a machine. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 253, 860, 271]]<|/det|> The graph shows how the count rate at the detector varies with the thickness of the paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 284, 920, 316]]<|/det|> The rollers squeeze the paper when the count rate at the detector drops below 12 counts per second and then stop squeezing when the count rate rises above 13 counts per second. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 327, 861, 549]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 631, 580]]<|/det|> What is the thickness of the paper coming out of the machine? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 592, 133, 609]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 592, 411, 609]]<|/det|> between \(0.40 \text{mm}\) and \(0.50 \text{mm}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 618, 133, 636]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 618, 411, 636]]<|/det|> between \(0.50 \text{mm}\) and \(0.60 \text{mm}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 645, 133, 663]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 645, 411, 663]]<|/det|> between \(0.60 \text{mm}\) and \(0.70 \text{mm}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 672, 133, 689]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 672, 411, 689]]<|/det|> between \(0.70 \text{mm}\) and \(0.80 \text{mm}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 714, 107, 733]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 714, 670, 733]]<|/det|> The table gives the orbital durations of planets in the Solar System. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 744, 905, 813]]<|/det|>
